ZKVM-1366: Add way to use cuda to compute control id for bootstrap
candidates.body:
This lets us compute the control id for bootstrap using the GPU.
It significantly speeds up bootstrap when enabled since doing these hashes on the CPU can take a long time.

candidates.title: ZKVM-1360: Drop legacy code and bump versions
ZKVM-1359: Remove extra copies from extract_zkr
candidates.body:
There are extra copies going on here when we realloc the `Vec` inside `read_to_end` and when we call `Vec::from`.

The larger the zkr the more of an issue this is. The zip format should have the size of the entry in it, so we can do better.

Additionally the cast from `[u8]` -> `[u32]` is one of higher alignment and kinda questionable. bytemuck will crash if the alignment is not high enough and likely or allocation aligns all allocations at > 4, but if we use a different memory allocator in the future this might not be true.

This was just something small I noticed when reading the recent recursion witgen GPU patch.

candidates.title: ZKVM-1357: Update dependencies
ZKVM-1344: Migrate recursion witgen to GPU
ZKVM-1342: Fix an issue with sys_read where it would read past the end of the
candidates.body:
supplied buffer, or fail in other ways.

The branch that had the issue was in the v2 kernel and only taken when the read is greater than 1024. By beefing up the test to do larger reads we can see the bug trigger.

The sys_read syscall would pass arguments in registers a0-a4. The first 3 registers (a0, a1, a2) are common to all the ecall_read syscalls. These are `syscall_ptr`, `buf`, and 'len`. The last two arguments (a3, ar) are `fd` and `nwords`.

On v2, we implement ecall_read differently where it accepts `fd`, `buf`, `len` as the first three common arguments. We end up adapting the API in the v2 kernel. The kernel calls the host ecall_read from kernel code. We stash the `syscall_ptr` in `fd` (the new ecall_read's `fd` argument not to be confused with sys_read's `fd` argument) and `buf` and `len` in their respective arguments, these are passed via kernel registers.

In the host ecall_read handler we unpack and adapt these arguments (the kernel registers a1 and a2) before calling into the syscall_read code (which we know to do thanks to a0) passing the two needed values (`buf` and `len` directly through).

Once in the syscall code we read the two other arguments, the actual `fd` and `nbytes` from the user register directly.

The return values are also different and there is code to adapt that including another ecall_read call to ferry the result, but its not relevant to the issue.

This all works fine, until we deal with reads greater than 1024. The new ecall API has the limitation of only doing reads <= 1024. So if we do reads >= 1024 the v2 kernel has to break up the read into smaller reads. This happens in the Rust implemented part of the kernel, and this is only taken for sys_read, the other syscalls aren't able to deal with chunking at all.

When we do this chunking though, we forget about the other sys_read arguments, in particular the value stored in a4. This value also contains the length and needs to be updated. By not updating it, the sys_read call does unexpected stuff, including reading not enough or too much.

candidates.title: ZKVM-1328: Add xtask extract-elf subcommand
candidates.body:
This command simply extracts the user and kernel elfs from a risc0 binfmt file.

This has been useful to have so things like `objdump` /   `gdb` / `llvm-dwarf-dump` can be run on the user elf.

candidates.title: ZKVM-1299: Fix SemVer checks for 2.0.1 release

candidates.title: ZKVM-1295: Add a lock-file for the SemVer checks
candidates.body:
This lock-file allows to lock-down the basline version being used for crates.

It solves a problem we have where as soon as we publish we may end up breaking the semver-checks for main. This allows us to update the main semver-checks when we want. (by deleting the lock-file)

candidates.title: ZKVM-1277: Update bn256 and p256 examples to latest patches
candidates.body: Update the dependencies of our bn256 and p256 examples to used the substrate bn and RustCrypto elliptic curves tagged versions that have been updated to use the latest release of `risc0-bigint2` for their precompiles.

candidates.title: ZKVM-1276: Add an xtask command that edits crate versions
candidates.body:
This is similar to `cargo set-version` except that it allows for relative changes (e.g. keeping the version but adding / removing `-rc.x`)

examples:
```
cargo xtask update-crate-version --package risc0-groth16 --bump-patch # e.g. 2.0.0 -> 2.0.1
cargo xtask update-crate-version --package risc0-groth16 --bump-major # e.g. 2.1.0 -> 3.0.0
cargo xtask update-crate-version --add-rc 2 # no --package argument means all packages
cargo xtask update-crate-version --remove-rc --add-rc 4 # update rc number to 4
```

candidates.title: ZKVM-1273: Widen file-lock around rzup install command
candidates.body:
`rzup` didn't really handle concurrent `install` commands being issued on the same machine. I'm not sure I believe that it ever did really.

It did have a file-lock used when downloading a file, but this wasn't sufficient since it didn't hold the lock long enough. Replace this file locking with a new lock that is taken for the duration of installation.

Also, we can't delete the lock-file when we are done with it, because you might delete a lock-file which another process has locked.

candidates.title: ZKVM-1267: Bump versions to fix SemVer checks after 2.0.0 release
candidates.body:
This bumps the following versions for the following reasons:

- `risc0-build`: patch bump due to 1.85 related changes
- `risc0-circuit-rv32im-sys`: patch bump to match release branch
- `risc0-circuit-rv32im`: minor bump due to hackenproof bug fix
- `risc0-r0vm`: patch bump due to change in version requirement of `risc0-circuit-rv32im`
- `risc0-zkvm-platform`: patch bump to match release branch
- `risc0-zkvm`: patch bump due to hackenproof bug fix changing an example, and version requirement increase of `risc0-circuit-rv32im` 
- `risc0-bigint2`: patch bump due to change in version requirement of `risc0-zkvm`

And the following additional bumps due to the recent new Poseidon254 CUDA kernel
- `risc0-groth16`: patch bump due to change in version requirement of `risc0-binfmt`
- `risc0-binfmt`: patch bump due to change in version requirement of `risc0-zkp`
- `risc0-zkp`: minor bump due to new public functions
- `risc-sys`: minor bump due to new public functions
- `risc0-circuit-rv32im-sys`: patch bump due to change in version requirement of `sspark`
- `risc0-circuit-recursion-sys`: patch bump due to change in version requirement of `sspark`
- `risc0-circuit-recursion`: minor bump due to new public functions

candidates.title: ZKVM-1241: Support for dumping and replaying segments
candidates.body:
* During execution, if `RISC0_DUMP_PATH` is set and an error occurs, serialize the current segment and write it to the specified path.
* `r0vm --segment` can be used to replay this segment later, possibly with extra debug tracing.

candidates.title: [release-2.0]: Add missing -rc.2 to 3 crates
candidates.body: I made a mistake and somehow got the version number wrong for these crates. I want to fix it in crates.io by republishing these crates with the right version and yanking the old version. This is in large part due to fixing the semver checks, but also for posterity.

candidates.title: ZKVM-1224: Add ABI version number to ProgramBinary; Check version in zkVM
candidates.body:
This adds a new header to the ProgramBinary. It stores it on disk as a list of enum values encoded using `postcard`. I wanted to use `bincode` at first, but it doesn't support `no_std` usage. It ignores values that it doesn't know about, potentially allowing for future versions of the header to still be decoded even if they contain new kinds of header values.

The value of this version is checked in the zkVM and an error is thrown if it doesn't match the one value we currently know about. This will prevent version 2.0.0 of the zkVM from attempting to execute guest programs built by newer version of the code. Also, this will allow future versions of zkVM to detect older versions of guest programs and handle that appropriately.

candidates.title: Merge main; Append rc.2 to the version; Bump risc0-build-kernel major verison
candidates.body:
This PR does the following:

- Merge main in by reverting last commit and doing a merge commit
- Append "-rc.2" to all the versions
- Bump the major version number for `risc0-build-kernel` due to breaking change on main
- Downgrade the major version number for `risc0-build` to 2.0.1
- Reapply the updates to ci.yml that were reverted

candidates.title: ZKVM-1222: Implement new SemVer checks
candidates.body:
This patch implements the new SemVer checks we have discussed as a new `xtask` command

It first runs `cargo-semver-checks` via its Rust API normally, then it adds our check for patch releases by doing a new check.
This new check basically runs `cargo publish` on crates where the current version number matches the published version number and compares the version that would be published with the version that is published and if there are any changes, we require a bump of the version number.

This PR also enables the new checks in CI replacing the existing checks. It doesn't move to make it be required yet, I thought we would try it out for a bit before blocking commits behind it.
